author: Fedor Zarkhin | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: Umpqua Community College shooting: What we know so far
text:
As Roseburg continued to grieve after the shooting that left 10 dead and nine injured Thursday, Oct. 1, new reports Saturday revealed how the gunman died, what his family had to say, and more.
Here are Saturday's main developments:
1. Gunman Christopher Harper-Mercer, 26, killed himself after exchanging gunfire with police , the Douglas County Sheriff's office said. Two Roseburg police detectives were in the area on another case and were the first to respond to the shooting. Harper-Mercer opened fire as soon as he saw them, and the detectives fired back. Harper-Mercer retreated suddenly, and the detectives found him in a hall. Harper-Mercer died on scene.
2. The gunman's family released this statement Saturday:
"We are shocked and deeply saddened by the horrific events that unfolded on Thursday, October 1. Our thoughts, our hearts and our prayers go out to all of the families of those who died and were injured."
In an interview with CNN , Harper-Mercer's father said he didn't know how his son amassed an arsenal of guns.
"How is it so easy to get all these guns?" Mercer said.
3. Two women shot by Harper-Mercer remained in critical condition at Springfield hospital Saturday morning. One was shot in the head and the other was shot in the abdomen and chest. Another victim was in the hospital in fair condition. As of Friday evening, two victims were at Mercy Medical Center, one in critical and one in fair condition.
4. The emergency alert system at Umpqua Community College may have failed to activate during the shooting, college faculty said. Three associate professors told The Oregonian/OregonLive they didn't get emergency notifications that were supposed to show up on their computers. Two professors who said they should have received emergency text messages said they did not.
5. The Umpqua Community College campus will reopen Monday , Oct. 5. Classes will be canceled through Friday, Oct. 9. Student activities are cancelled until Monday, Oct. 5.
